entry.title: ç”¨pythonå†™ä¸€ä¸ªè±†ç“£å°ç»„çš„çˆ¬è™«ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰
entry.content:
ç”¨pythonå†™ä¸€ä¸ªè±†ç“£å°ç»„çš„çˆ¬è™«ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰

è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ç¯‡å¤¹æ‚ç€å¤§é‡ç§è´§çš„â€œæŠ€æœ¯è´´â€ã€‚

è±†ç“£æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç¥å¥‡çš„ç½‘ç«™ã€‚æˆ‘å¤§æ¦‚æ˜¯åœ¨07å¹´çš„æ—¶å€™çŸ¥é“æœ‰è±†ç“£è¿™ä¸ªç½‘ç«™ï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨é«˜è€ƒä¹‹åæœ‰ä¸€æ®µæ—¶é—´æ•´å¤©æ³¡åœ¨ä¸Šè¾¹ï¼Œæ¯çœ‹å®Œä¸€éƒ¨ç”µå½±å°±ä¸Šå»æ ‡è®°ä¸ºâ€œçœ‹è¿‡â€ï¼Œå†™ä¸ªçŸ­è¯„ï¼Œä¹æ­¤ä¸ç–²ã€‚è±†ç“£fmä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ‘éå¸¸å–œæ¬¢çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œæˆ‘æ›¾ç»æœ€å–œæ¬¢çš„äº‹æƒ…ä¹‹ä¸€å°±æ˜¯ä¸€è¾¹å¬ç€ç§äººç”µå°ï¼Œä¸€è¾¹åœ¨é˜¿å°”æ³•åŸé€›æ¥é€›å»ï¼ˆåæ¥é˜¿å°”æ³•åŸå…³æ‰äº†ï¼‰ã€‚å†å†™ä¸‹å»å°±è¦å†™æˆè±†ç“£çš„è½¯æ–‡äº†ï¼Œå“ˆã€‚ä¸è¿‡ç¡®å®æƒ³è¯´ï¼Œä½œä¸ºæœ€æ—©çš„ä¸€æ‰¹90ï¼Œè±†ç“£åœ¨å½“æ—¶æœ‰ç‚¹åƒæ˜¯æ—©å‡ å¹´å‰çš„çŸ¥ä¹ï¼Œä¹Ÿåƒæ˜¯40å¹´ä»£çš„é­”å…½ä¸–ç•Œï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»¤äººæ€€å¿µçš„å°ç¤¾åŒºã€‚

è±†ç“£å°ç»„ä¸å¾—ä¸è¯´æ˜¯è±†ç“£æ¯”è¾ƒæˆåŠŸçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­äº§å“ï¼Œå½“æ—¶æˆ‘åˆæ¬¡æ¥è§¦çš„æ—¶å€™å°±è§‰å¾—ï¼Œâ€œæ¯”ç™¾åº¦è´´å§ä¸çŸ¥é“é«˜åˆ°å“ªé‡Œå»äº†â€ã€‚ä¹Ÿè®¸æ˜¯å»ºç­‘å­¦çš„æ•™è‚²èƒŒæ™¯è®©æˆ‘åŸ¹å…»äº†ä¸€ä¸çš„å®¡ç¾è§‚ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æ˜¯è§‰å¾—è±†ç“£å°ç»„é‡Œçš„å¹¿å‘Šè™½ç„¶ä¹Ÿæœ‰ä½†è¿œæ²¡æœ‰é‚£ä¹ˆäººå‘½å…³å¤©ï¼Œæ€»ä¹‹ï¼Œçœ‹ç€èˆ’æœã€‚è¿™ä¸ç®—æ˜¯å¯¹è±†ç“£çš„å¤¸å¥–ï¼Œå› ä¸ºäº‹å®ä¸Šä»…ä»…å°±äº§å“æœ¬èº«å°†è±†ç“£å°ç»„ä¸ç™¾åº¦è´´å§ç›¸æ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œå°±è¶³å¤Ÿä»¤äººç”Ÿç–‘æˆ‘æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯åœ¨é»‘è±†ç“£äº†ã€‚ä¸æ˜¯çš„ï¼Œæˆ‘åªæ˜¯åœ¨å®¢è§‚åœ°è¡¨è¾¾ä½œä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªç”¨æˆ·çš„ç”¨æˆ·ä½“éªŒè€Œå·²ã€‚ä¸è¿‡éœ€è¦æ¾„æ¸…çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘å¯¹äºç™¾åº¦çš„ä¸é½¿åªå±€é™äºå…¶å†³ç­–å±‚çš„æ‰€ä½œæ‰€ä¸ºï¼ˆæˆ–è€…æ˜¯ä¸ä½œä¸ºï¼Ÿï¼‰ï¼Œè‡³äºæ‰€æœ‰å‹¤å‹¤æ³æ³åœ°ç ç€ä»£ç çš„å·¥ç¨‹å¸ˆã€äº§å“ç»ç†å’Œè®¾è®¡å¸ˆç­‰ç­‰ï¼Œè°ä¸æ˜¯åœ¨å…»å®¶ç³Šå£å‘¢ï¼Ÿ

ä¸‰ã€ä½¿ç”¨beautiful soupè§£æç½‘é¡µ

æ¥ç€å°±æ˜¯æŠ½å–æƒ³è¦çš„ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚æœ¬æ–‡åªæƒ³åšä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯è·å–å¸–å­çš„æ ‡é¢˜ï¼Œå‘å¸–äººï¼Œå›å¤æ•°ï¼Œæœ€åå›å¤æ—¶é—´ä»¥åŠå‘å¸–äººä¸»é¡µé“¾æ¥å’Œå¸–å­é“¾æ¥ã€‚

ç„¶è€Œä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆéœ€è¦é“¾æ¥å‘¢ï¼Ÿä¾æˆ‘è‡ªå·±çš„ç»éªŒï¼Œäººæœ‰çš„æ—¶å€™çœŸçš„ä¼šæŠ‘åˆ¶ä¸ä½å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒå»çœ‹çœ‹å‘äº†â€œå”å¸…è¿˜éœ¸é“ï¼Œæœ‰é’±â€è¿™æ ·å­çš„å¸–å­æ˜¯ä½•æ–¹é«˜å¯Œå¸…ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¼šæƒ³è¦å»å›´è§‚ä¸€ä¸‹â€œæ¥¼ä¸»å¥³ï¼Œæ‡‚çš„æ¥â€è¿™æ ·çš„å¸–å­ï¼Œæ£€éªŒä¸€ä¸‹è‡ªå·±æ‡‚ä¸æ‡‚é©å‘½æ„å¿—æ˜¯å¦åšå®šã€‚å¼€ç©ç¬‘å•¦ï¼Œå…¶å®ä¿ç•™é“¾æ¥çš„ç›®çš„æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†åšæ›´ä¸ºå¤æ‚çš„çˆ¬è™«ï¼Œå³è®©çˆ¬è™«å¯ä»¥ç»§ç»­é¡ºç€é“¾æ¥çˆ¬ä¸‹å»ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ‰æœ‰å¯èƒ½å¾—å‡ºæ‰€æœ‰ç”¨æˆ·çš„å…³ç³»å›¾[^2]ã€‚

entry.title: Wordlist Story 1
entry.content:
####Chapter one (not finished)
The underground world

Everything changed the day my foster parents took me out of that frigid orphanage, the place was much more a place for contrition than parentless children.

The unidimensional world is not lifeless. If Iâ€™m being retentive and still have the mental agility, it could be a long story that may overwhelm you with the details. However, I have such an infamous memory that I may jeopardize the accuracy of the story if I unscrupulously fabricate the parts those seem blurred to me. In order to be dutiful storyteller, it better be terse. Donâ€™t worry, itâ€™s not going to be an insipid one though.

It was about seventy years ago that I got adopted by a couple who are both scientists. I used to be a flabby boy back then and as a result got beaten up a lot by bullies in the orphanage, the Clemency of Jesus state orphanage. This experience may be the cause of the fickleness in my personality since I always felt my future was chancy and devoid of hope. Everything changed the day my step parents took me out of that frigid orphanage, the place was much more a place for contrition than parentless children.

My foster father was a prestigious physicist and Marry, my foster mother, was also a physicist as well as a profound engineer. For a long time, we lived a spartan life in a villa located on the ridge of a dead volcano that its crater is within a hundred yard from our front door. Itâ€™s nonthreatening, of course. The alienation from mainstream society could be a boon to someone agoraphobic, but not to an ten-year-old boy. Very soon, my congenital proclivity for exploration was galvanized. One sultry afternoon of August 18th 1946, I had a conversation with my father which lead to the start of our story.

â€œPapa, are we derelicts of modern society?â€ I asked in a disgruntled voice.â€

â€œOh my little Pinsent, where does this platitudinous remark come from?â€, my father seems a little surprised as well as amused. He untied the buckle of a machine which was used to irradiate some ore and the experiment stopped. As he turned face to me the glow of the ore ceased in an anticlimactic way.

â€œIs it because of defamations those vitriolic people spread about you and mama or they trying to encumber your work?â€ I jump up to papaâ€™s desk, sitting abreast that elaborate machine. â€œMama told me that they even excised you from the academy, itâ€™s implausible!â€ I murmured.

â€œSon, someday you may realize that being supplanted is not necessarily a punishment but to gain opulent amount of free time. As long as one belongs to a certain organization he has to show conformity, otherwise you might be considered a haughty and immature person.â€ My father responded in a sedate voice, looked me in the eye. It was like he was trying to engrave this into my head, but then he smiled, with understanding of his sonâ€™s boredom, â€œDo you want to know what this outmoded machine is?â€

â€œWhat? Outmodedâ€¦ Then what is it, papa? Who made it?â€ I couldnâ€™t move away my eyes from that dumbbell-like machine, which seems unworldly that not likely to be created by man. My father was a physicist with talent and towering acadamical achievements, this is one thing. But this machine? Itâ€™s just so deviant for a scientific equipment.

â€œI donâ€™t want to disillusion you, my son. But it was just a gift from an anterior friend. That friend of mine tried to provoke me by sending a thing that nobody knows what it is and where it comes from.â€ He frowned, â€œLast several years I was haunted by self-doubt that I may never be able to reveal its inherent nature. Of course I have some hypotheses, but all of them lack of corroboration.â€

As far I as can remember, my father never tended to deplore the comic act of his immature friend, in inverse he was so possessed of digging out its secret which seemed undecipherable as if he had a rival to compete with. He had never been such a zealot, but for some time even my mother thought heâ€™s a â€œstrange machine fanaticâ€œ. My mother may preserved an appearance of nonchalance, but her insight far transcends my fahterâ€™s. With a cursory glance she drawed a conclusion that this machine must be alien.

â€œHow can you be so sure,â€ My father asked on dinner table later that day, â€œYou need to do repetitive reaffirmations before repudiating my hypothesis.â€

(To be continuedâ€¦)
entry.summary:
####Chapter one (not finished)
The underground world

Everything changed the day my foster parents
